When you have Advantages or Disadvantages, treat every die as separate in terms of critical rolls. For example, if you have two Advantages and happen to roll three '10's, you would then flip a coin for each die (3 in total.) Since only the highest result is kept, you will likely be able to discard any critical failures, barring the unfortunate instance where you fail all three coun tosses.

Instead of flipping a coin, you could instead roll the die again, treating an odd number as a critical failure and an even number as a critical success.
Instead of flipping a coin, you could achieve the same results by using d10ish dice in place of the normal d10 dice. Each d10ish die is a 20-sided die that has 1 through 9 twice and 0 and 10 only once. Rolling a 0 on a d10ish die is a critical failure while rolling a 10 is a critical success.
The same effect of a d10ish die can be achieved using a 20-sided die by subtracting 10 from any result of 10 and higher, with a 0 (10 on the d20) being a critical failure and a 10 (20 on the d20) being a critical success.

item.title: Damage
item.description: TODO

item.title: Damage Type
item.description:
Damage Type is a way of categorizing damage based on how it would interact with armor, the body, the mind, and even the soul.
All damage is categorized using a Major Damage Type and a Minor Damage Type.
The Major Damage Types are: Solid, Fluid, Ethereal, and True.
The Minor Damage Types are: Blunt, Sharp, Shock, Fire, Ice, Caustic and Planar.
Generally speaking, the Major Damage Types can be thought of as follows:

Solid Damage is slowed down by armor or physical defenses before it hits you.
Fluid Damage can seep or permeate through or around some physical defenses.
Ethereal Damage comes to you through non-physical means, bypassing physical defenses altogether.
True Damage is very rare and cannot be blocked by any defense of any kind. It bypasses your Shield and cannot be reduced in any way. Unlike the other Major Damage Types, True Damage is generally not paired with a Minor Damage Type.
Below is a chart that provides basic examples of descriptions of what each Major/Minor combination might represent in your travels. (Not all combos are represented here. Your GM may use other combos or create a new Minor Damage Type altogether.)

item.title: Deception
item.description:
Deception is a Social Stat representing how well you can do things like:

Lie, mislead, trick, or manipulate someone.
Intimidate someone through secretly empty threats.
Charm someone while pretending to be someone you're not.
Perform faked stage magic, deceptive arts, or pretend to be someone or something you're not.

item.title: Defense
item.description: A Defense is applied to incoming Abilities and effects that may cause you Damage or inflict a Status Condition on you. There are three types of Defenses: Immunities, Resistances, and Weaknesses.

item.title: Dice Shorthand
item.description: Dice are often referred to using a Dice Shorthand consisting of a 'd' proceeded by the number of dice to be rolled and followed by a number of faces that the dice should have. The Kleptonomicon uses a d10 for almost everything, which is a 10-sided die.

item.title: Diplomacy Skill
item.description:
Diplomacy is a Social Skill that determines how well you can do things like:

Temporarily stop a fight to negotiate something.
Barter when trading goods.
Get a better reward when accepting a quest.
Calm or soothe a creature or animal (often with Insight.)

item.title: Disadvantage
item.description:
For each Disadvantage that you have on a Test you will roll an additional d10. The lowest d10 will then be used as the die result when calculating your Score the Test. A Disadvantage usually remains in effect until the circumstances that imposed it are no longer relevant. Abilities that give you a Disadvantage will generally describe how long it lasts.
When you have both Advantages and Disadvantages, they cancel each-other out at a rate of one-to-one. After canceling out, the total number of Advantages or Disadvantages that remain is capped at 3. This means you will only ever need 4 or fewer 10-sided dice for any one Test.
If a Critical Roll is rolled as one of the dice in a Test with a Disadvantage, resolve the Critical Roll for each die separately before determining which die is the highest or lowest. This may mean ignoring a Critical Success, as there may be a lower die result.

item.title: Distance
item.description:
Most Abilities have a limited range in terms of what they can target or what area they affect. Unless a Distance is described as being "True...", walls and other obstructions will obscure what's behind them, meaning those things don't count as being within the stated Distance. The following colloquial terms are used to refer to the most common Distances. While The Kleptonomicon is written primarily for play using the Theater of the Mind, real distances are also provided for help with adapting the game for play with miniatures and a map.

Up to about 1 meter (or yard) away.

Up to about 4 meters (or yards) away.

Up to about 8 meters (or yards) away.

Up to about 16 meters (or yards) away.

Up to about 200 meters (or yards) away.

Up to about 400 meters (or yards) away.

item.title: Effect Duration
item.description: An Effect Duration defines the maximum amount of in-game time that an Ability's effect can stay active.

item.title: Enchanting Skill
item.description:
Enchanting is a Tuning-based Skill that allows you to do things like:

Recall information about magic that involves enchanting creatures and objects. This includes spells that buff or debuff existing objects and creatures. It also includes charms and the creation of magic items.
Recall information about unnatural creatures, such as aberrations, cursed beings, and unnaturally ascended beings. This includes gods and other entities that have been warped or modified from their natural state.

item.title: Encounter
item.description: An Encounter is a more strict, turn-based phase of play. During an Encounter, the amount of things you can do and the total distance you can move is limited.

item.title: End Phase
item.description: The End Phase of an Encounter marks a transition back to Freeplay.

item.title: Episode
item.description: An Episode is a stretch of the game that generally spans only one or two sessions of play. During an Episode, things like healing and Abilities will be limited in their total number of uses. At the start of each Episode, you may be able to use Episodic Abilities at the end of the Opening Credits. At the end of each Episode, you will be able to reset many values, like your Health and Vitality, as a part of the Closing Credits.

item.title: Episodic
item.description: The Episodic Ability Time indicates that an Ability is used at the start of a new Encounter. Episodic Ability effects are generally limited to the arch of each Episode, so any unspent points or unused effects will be lost the moment the next Episode starts and the Ability is used again. In the same vein, using up all of your Episodic effects before an Episode ends may mean you have to wait till the next Episode, and the next use of your Episodic Ability, to use its effects again.

item.title: Exhausting
item.description:
Abilities with the "Exhausting" Penalty (or "Exhausting Abilities") impose one stack of Exhausted if you Pass their Test.
All future Exhausting Ability Tests have one Disadvantage for each stack of Exhausted that you have.

item.title: Experience Point
item.description:
Experience Points mark your progress toward gaining a Level. The GM will give you Experience Points for exploring the world, uncovering story, accomplishing hidden objectives, and completing Encounters.
Once you reach 20 Experience Points, you will gain a Level and reset your Experience Points to 0.
For more on Experience Points and Leveling Up, see chapter 08 Tracker Boxes.

item.title: Expire
item.description: When an Ability is Prepared, it is added to your Character Sheet. When it Expires, it is removed from your Character Sheet and can no longer be used (until it can be Prepared once more.) In the description of how to Prepare an Ability, you will also find the conditions that, when met, will mean the ability Expires. The most common Expiration occurs after you have used the Prepared Ability once.

item.title: Exploration Skill
item.description: TODO

item.title: Exploration Stat
item.description:
The Exploration Stats represent your generic capability when it comes to exploring and performing other non-social activities. The Exploration Stats are:

Might. The front-line force of the group. Favored stat of skilled strikers, bulky athletes, and seasoned warriors. Affects your Fighter Abilities most.
Artifice. The back-line specialist of the group. Favored stat of dexterous fighters, skillful snipers, and nimble-handed craftsmen. Affects your Specialist Abilities most.
Tuning. The magical conduit of the group. Favored stat of Dark mages and enlightened sages. Affects your Mage Abilities most.

item.title: Falling
item.description:
#secondary_action #primary_action #secondary_action
Falling
If ever you fall more than 2u, you may suffer some Damage.
If you are falling less than 3u, you are fine and can ignore the fall. For any amount greater than that, the distance that you fall correlates directly with the amount of Damage that you take.
Whenever you start to fall, the fall itself may not be resolved until you have had a chance to take some actions on your Turn. If you fall 3u or more, but less than 10u, you can take a #secondary_action on your turn before the fall, and its damage, is resolved. If you fall 10u or more, but less than 100u, you can take a #primary_action or a #secondary_action on your turn before the fall, and its damage, is resolved. If you fall more than 100u, you can take an entire Turn. At the end of your turn, you will fall 100u worth of distance. This is repeated until you have a turn where you are falling less than 100u, at which point you will hit the ground and take 100 Solid/Blunt Damage. A distance of 100u is considered your terminal velocity, meaning you will never suffer more than 100 Solid/Blunt Damage from a fall.
Since a fall is resolved on your Turn, there is a chance you can save other falling players by taking certain actions of your Turn. If ever you wish to catch another character, each of you will take only half of the total fall damage, rounded down.
There are also many spells and some items, like a net, that can also help you catch, or slow down, a falling character.

item.title: Favor
item.description: A Favor can be used on any Test to gain an Advantage. At the start of each Episode you can gain Favors equal to your Luck Stat.

item.title: Flavor
item.description:
A Flavor changes the base effects of an Item or Ability.
You must choose one Flavor when you first gain the Item or Ability. That Item or Ability retains that Flavor forever (though anything that would let you replace an Item or Ability lets you replace your Flavor as well.)

item.title: Fleeting Condition
item.description: Fleeting Conditions are Status Conditions that loses 1 Stack at the end of each of your Turns, unless you got the stack on that same turn.

item.title: Free Action
item.description: An Ability with an Ability Time of "Free Action" requires that it be your Turn to perform the Ability. Unlike an Action, no Beat is required for a Free Action to take effect.

item.title: Free Reaction
item.description: A 'Free Reaction' Ability Time on an Ability means that that Ability can be performed at any point in an Encounter, not just on your Turn, provided that the Reaction Trigger has occurred. Unlike a Reaction, a Free Reaction does not require that you spend a Beat. Only one Reaction or Free Reaction can be used per Reaction Trigger per character.

item.title: Freeplay
item.description:
The Freeplay phase of the game is more story-driven and does not have a strict turn-order or limit to what Abilities you can try to use. Instead, it is up to the GM to balance play and make sure that the events unfolding make sense with the flow of time and the situation at hand.
For a detailed overview of Freeplay and its rules, see chapter 04 Phases of Play.

item.title: Friendship Point
item.description: Friendship Points represent your ability to connect with magically Jealous Items and keep them happy. At Level 1 you will have no Friendship Points, but can gain them whenever you gain a Fine Wealth Skill Improvement.

item.title: Game Master
item.description: The Game Master (or GM) is the player that act as the lead storyteller for your the game. The GM creates and manages the world and the challenges found within it. The GM also role-plays for all Non-Player Character (or NPCs) that you come across in the world. The GM acts as a referee and the final arbiter on all rules. The GM can choose to replace or ignore rules if it helps improve the experience for everyone playing.

item.title: Glossary
Glyph
item.description:
#Ethereal_Plane
A Glyph is an arcane entity created by a Glyphic Spell and appears as a rune, set of runes, sigil, or magic circle that is only visible on the #Ethereal_Plane. Glyphs can be connected together to form a Glyph Network.

item.title: Glyph Ability
item.description: TODO

item.title: Glyph Command
item.description: TODO

item.title: Glyph Network
item.description: A Glyph Network refers to a set of Glyphs that have all been connected together and that interact with one another. Each Glyph in the network can send Glyph Commands to all other Glyphs on the network, possibly triggering Glyph Abilities. These connections can form complex behavior, like security networks with monitoring and automated defenses.

item.title: Glyphic Ability
item.description:
#Ethereal_Plane #Glyph_Spell
Glyphic Spells have a set of Shared Glyph Rules that you should learn before taking on any of the Glyphic Spells.
The Glyph Spell List is organized into two sub-lists:

Major Glyph Spells - The 4 more common and useful Glyphic Spells.
Minor Glyph Spells - A collection of more niche Glyphic Spells.

Networks of Glyphs are often used for security and magical traps, but can be used to weave your magic into the world around you in many other ways.
Unless otherwise stated, all Glyphs created by Glyphic Spells have the following shared characteristics:

The Glyph appears as a rune, set of runes, sigil, or magic circle that is only visible on the #Ethereal_Plane.
When creating a new Glyph, you can extend the casting time, spending additional Actions to specify Glyph Abilities to be added to the Glyph. Possible Glyph Abilities are described by each Glyphic Spell. Unless otherwise stated, the same Glyph Ability can be used more than once, provided that you specify different details each time. Glyph Abilities cannot be altered or changed after you have finished casting a Glyph.
A Glyph can be connected to other Glyphs to form a network. When creating a new Glyph, you can connect it to any other Glyph within 1u of it. Many Glyph Abilities can send out a Glyph Command based on a specified trigger. When a Glyph sends out a Glyph Command, it is instantly received by all other connected Glyphs on a network (no matter how many Glyphs exist between them), though only some will recognize the Glyph Command and activate an associated Glyph Ability. For some of the Glyphic Spells in the list below, you may need to write down the Glyph Commands used by a network, as a skilled Glyph hacker can figure out what Glyph Commands are being used and twist them to their will.
All Glyphs have the following Glyph Ability options in addition to any described in their #Glyph_Spell:
Upon receiving a specified Glyph Command, a Glyph can permanently dismiss itself.
Upon receiving a specified Glyph Command, a Glyph can temporarily dismiss itself for an amount of time specified at casting time.
When temporarily or permanently dismissed, the Glyph can issue a Glyph Command.
If a Glyph is described as being attached to a solid surface, the Glyph will be permanently dismissed if it is moved more than 2u away from its original location. (For example, moving a box more than 2u in any direction would dismiss any Glyph attached to that box.)

item.title: Glyphic Spell
item.description:
#Ethereal_Plane
A Glyphic Spell is a spell that can create a Glyph, which appears as a rune, set of runes, sigil, or magic circle that is only visible on the #Ethereal_Plane. Glyphs can be connected together to form a Glyph Network that is often used for security networks and other automated effects.

item.title: Good
item.description: TODO

item.title: Group Test
item.description:
A Group Test occurs when all Players make a Test together. At the end of the Group Test, the lowest Score is used for the entire group. Before the Group Test ends, however, players that roll well can help other players that did not fare so well.
First, all players involved roll their Test as normal. Then, based on a player's individual Score, they can help other players improve their Score:

[7..] You can give another player an Advantage to their Test.
[10..] You can give two Advantages out to other Player(s) for their Test(s).
By giving Advantages to other players, you can potentially turn their Fail into a Pass.

item.title: Health
item.description:
Your Health Point Bank serves as the primary pool of points from which damage is subtracted.
Damage is first subtracted from your Shield Point Bank. If your Shield reaches or is at 0, then all remaining damage is subtracted from your Health. If your Health reaches or is at 0, then any remaining damage causes you to lose one Vitality Point. Losing a Vitality Point inflicts a Wound. If your Health and Vitality both reach zero, then you die.
You can attempt to Dodge an incoming attack, provided that you have points for it.

item.title: History Skill
item.description:
History is a Might-based Skill that allows you to do things like:

Recall oral stories, legends, customs, religions, or other historical info that existed or occurred more than 5 years ago. This knowledge can include battles, heroes, politics, etc.
Recall beliefs of religions more than 5 years old.
Recall and perform traditions or traditional ceremonies with accuracy and the acceptance of those familiar with such rites.

item.title: Homebrew
item.description:
Rules or content created by the community that are not found in this book.
Your GM will generally inform you ahead of time when homebrew rules will be used. You may also be able to propose your own homebrew rules or content, but it will need to be approved by the GM before it can be used at the table.

item.title: Immunity
item.description:
An Immunity is a Defense that automatically blocks all incoming Damage of a certain Damage Type or all incoming Stacks of a certain Status Condition. If the incoming Damage Type or Status Condition type does not match the one listed in the Immunity then the Immunity does not take effect. Some Immunities may list additional requirements that must be met as well before the Immunities takes effect.
An Immunity may also list other effects. These side effects become active immediately after the matched Damage or Status Condition has been mitigated.

item.title: Improvement
item.description:
An Improvement lets you choose a Stat or Skill and gain a benefit, depending on what type of Stat or Skill you chose:

For Social Skills, you no longer have to roll that Skill with a Disadvantage.
For all other Stats and Skills, you can increase their Modifier by 1.
Each Social Skill can only be Improved once. Each Skill can only be improved twice. Each Stat can have any number of Improvements, provided that you do not exceed a maximum amount for the Modifier that will be described by the Ability or Perk that granted you that Improvement.

item.title: Improvised Movement
item.description: An Improvised Movement Range defines both a distance and mode of travel available to you. On your Turn, you can spend Movement into your Movement Ranges to move in that Movement Range's mode of travel, up to the distance limit for that Movement Range. You must spend double the Movement when using an Improvised Movement Range instead of a regular Movement Range.

item.title: Insight
item.description:
Insight is a Social Stat representing how well you can do things like:

Read a person or creature for a peek at their inner thoughts and feelings.
Gain a peek into someone's true respectability or trustworthiness.
Determine if another player character is using Deception or Sincerity Stat.
Gain special insights into the social vulnerabilities of someone and use those vulnerabilities to poignantly apply pressure.
Perform a mentalist act on stage.
Communicate basic ideas to animals and other nature.
Determine if the person you are talking to has more info or other topics of interest. On a good roll, gain clues as to what those topics might be or even what tactics may get you there, like bringing up the importance of family or expressing distrust of a political figure.

item.title: Intimidation Skill
item.description:
Intimidation is a Social Skill that determines how well you can do things like:

Make a show of presence and posturing to illicit a response.
Threaten someone in some way.
Get someone to fear someone or something other than you.
Attempt to force a flight, fight, or freeze response.

item.title: Item
item.description:
Items are placed in the inventory box on your Character Sheet and can be used to perform that Item's Abilities, if it has them, or improvise clever solutions to the problems at hand. A majority of the Items you will gain will be gained through the Inventory Search Ability, which allows you to exchange Goods to perform a Wealth Skill Test that could yield you the item you seek.
You can always improvise any item feasibly found in the world, though a good many items can be found in the Item List appendix. The GM may also give you stronger, rarer items from the Special Item List.
Items can be sold using the Inventory Sell Ability while you are near a marketplace with 10 minutes or so.
Many Items will have Item Tags that give them extra rules and capabilities. A full list of Item Tags can be found in the Item Tag List appendix.

item.title: Item Grade
item.description:
Item Grade refers to the overall quality and condition of an Item. When using the Inventory Search Ability, most items will have a set of Item Grades that correlate with the following Score Ranges:

[..6] (F)lawed Items
[7..9] (C)ommon Items
[10..] (A)wesome Items
[10!] (S)uperior Items

item.title: Item Tag
item.description: An Item Tag represents a common set of rules shared by many different Items. All Item Tags can be found in the Item Tag List appendix.

item.title: Kleptonomica
item.description:
Kleptonomica refers to the fantasy world that this game takes place in with all of its rules-related mechanics and world building.
Not to be confused with the Kleptonomicon, which refers to this book and this Tabletop Roleplaying Game.

item.title: Kleptonomicon
item.description:
The Kleptonomicon refers to this book and this Tabletop Roleplaying Game.
On the other hand, Kleptonomica refers to the fantast world that the game takes place in with all of its rules-related mechanics and world building.

item.title: Knowledge Skill
item.description: The Knowledge Skills are a subset of the Exploration Skills focused on more situational skills. The six Knowledge Skills are Athletics, History, Rumor, Tinkering, Conjuring, and Enchanting.

item.title: Language Family
item.description:
The Language Families group all of the languages from the Language List into three groups: Primordial Languages, Mechanical Languages, and Organic Languages.
When asked to make a Language Skill Test, you will be required to roll with a Disadvantage if you do not know a Language from the same Language Family as your interlocutor.

item.title: Language Skill
item.description:
Language is a Social Skill that determines how well you can do things like:

Your ability to communicate with a native speaker of a language.
Your ability to speak to communicate basic ideas to someone that speaks a language similar to one you know.
Your ability to pick up on speech in languages you are less familiar with.
The Languages Skill will list with it which specific Languages that you are fluent in. When you are skilled in a Language, you can freely speak with anyone else that also knows that Language.
When you don't know a Language, you can still attempt to communicate very basic messages, relying on body language and expressions. Each of these simple messages will likely require a Test to be made to determine how well you communicated. Fail the Test and you may receive a bad interpretation.
All languages (apart from the Common Tongue) are sorted into three Language Families. If your language skills don't include a language within the same Language Families, you must make the Language Skill Test with a Disadvantage.

item.title: Level
item.description:
Your Level determines what upgrades and improvements you get when.
You will generally start the game at Level 1, unless the GM says otherwise. During the game, the GM will award you with Experience Points. For every 20 Experience Points that you gain, you will be able to Level Up. When you Level Up, you get to add to your overall Level and one Archetype Level, then gain the number and type of Abilities associated with that level along with one Perk.

item.title: Luck Stat
item.description: Represents your general level of Luck. Often rolled for circumstances that take no Skill, but rather pure happenstance. Luck also determines how many Favors you get at the start of an Episode at a rate of one-to-one.

item.title: Main Movement Range
item.description: The largest Movement Range found on your Character Sheet is your Total Movement Limit. At the start of each of your Turns you gain Movement equal to your Total Movement Limit.

item.title: Mastery
item.description: Mastery in a Social Skill means that you no longer have a Disadvantage when performing Tests for that Social Skill, regardless of which Social Stat is used. Each Social Skill can only gain Mastery once, except the Performance and Language Skills which can gain a Mastery for each new type of Performance or Language that you gain.

item.title: Mechanical Language
item.description:
Organic Language is a Language Family.
The Organic Languages are Languages that came to be out of order and logic or were placed or programmed in by a creator. These Languages lead to more strict and linear thinking toward a given life goal (though for some that causality may be flipped. It's hard to say.)
Example Organic Languages: Construct, Dwarvish, Giant, Orc, *Gem
*Most gems can only communicate in 1 or 2-word thoughts.
The full list of Organic Languages can be found in the Language List.

item.title: Modifier
item.description:
A Modifier, (sometimes called a "mod" for short), is a fixed value added to or subtracted from a dice roll. The shorthand for a modifier is written as a '+' or '-' followed by a number. When a modifier is preceded by Dice Shorthand, you will simply roll the dice specified, then add the modifier to the sum of the dice.
On your Character Sheet, you will find many named modifiers with no Dice Shorthand before them. In these cases the die rolled with the modifier will be a d10.

item.title: Movement
item.description: Your Movement is a resource used to move on your Turn. At the start of your Turn you gain a Movement equal to the largest Movement Range on your Character Sheet. Your Movement can be spent back into each Movement Ranges to travel in that way. You can only spend and move up to each individual Movement Range's limit, at which time that mode of travel becomes unavailable until your next Turn (or until the Movement Range is increased by an Ability.)

item.title: Movement Range
item.description: A Movement Range defines a mode of travel available to you and how far you can travel in that mode. On your Turn, you can spend Movement to enter a new mode of travel, using that mode's rules. Once the Movement spent on any one Movement Range reaches that range's limit, that mode of travel cannot be used any more until your Movement is regained at the start of your next Turn or by an Ability. Some Movement Ranges can be Interrupted, incurring consequences described in that Movement Range's description.

item.title: Noise
item.description:
There are 5 levels of Noise:

Silent. The course of action makes no noise.
Quiet. The course of action makes a whisper of a noise. Can be heard within a Swinging Distance.
Noisy. The course of action makes a talking amount of noise. Can be heard within a Spitting Distance
Loud. The course of action makes a yelling amount of noise or more. Can be heard within a Shooting Distance.

item.title: Non-Player Character
item.description: An NPC or Non-Player Character is a character played primarily by the GM.

item.title: Opening Credits
item.description:
Opening Credits happen at the start of each Episode. Each Player will introduce themselves and their Player Character and describe a 5 second, opening credits-style "clip" of your character. This scene does not have to have anything to do with the rest of the game, but should capture the essence of your character.
After that, anyone that has Episodic Abilities can use them. These Abilities often grant points or effects that can only be used during that same Episode.

item.title: Organic Language
item.description:
Organic Language is a Language Family.
The Organic Languages are Languages that are often inherent to the chaos of nature and often flow and drift, lacking structure and clear rules.
Example Organic Languages: Animal, Elvish, Fairy, Gnomish, Goblin, *Plant
*Most plants can only communicate in 1 or 2-word thoughts.
The full list of Organic Languages can be found in the Language List.

item.title: Passive
item.description: Passive is one of the possible Ability Times that an Ability can have. Unlike the other Ability Times, Passive Abilities do not need to be started and are instead always in effect.

item.title: Penalty
item.description: A Penalty describes a situation in which an Ability or Item will receive a negative addon to its usual Test or effect. Most Penalties will give you a Disadvantage if the described situation holds true.

item.title: Perception Skill
item.description: The Perception Skills are a subset of the Exploration Skills focused on your ability to gather different types of information from your surroundings. The three Perception Skills are Recon, Analysis, and Sensing.

item.title: Performance Skill
item.description:
Performance is a Social Skill that determines how well you can do things like:

Perform for a crowd in order to draw attention by impressing, scaring, annoying, etc.
Poignantly orate a sermon, battle plan, inspiration speech, etc.
You can also gain a skill in Performance for more specialized skills, such as singing, playing instruments, giving psychic readings, etc. There is no core list of what types of performances there are. Rather, you should try to pick one that would be interesting, fun, and fairly niche. Consider what your character might choose at a talent show or if they had to create an attention-grabbing distraction. It should be something they are good at performing. Discuss your performance ideas with your GM to ensure that it will work well in the world and story you are playing in.
Performance types also do not have to be based on one of the Social Stats, but can instead use one of the Exploration Skills as its main inspiration. For example, an 'acrobatics' or 'dance' performance may be rolled with your Athleticism Skill as its Modifier if your character relies more on physicality than inherent charisma.

item.title: Perk
item.description:
A Perk provides a generic improvement to your character.
Level Perks can improve your Stats, Skills, overall Health, and more. You can choose 1 Level Perk at each Level (including at Level 1.)
Archetype Perks improve capabilities in a more niche way that complements each Archetype. Whenever you add a Level to one of your Archetypes, you can choose 1 Archetype Perk for the Archetype you chose (including any of the initial Archetype Levels chosen at Level 1.) For example, if you add a Level to the Mage Archetype, yo may then choose a Mage Perk.
Fighter Perks, Rogue Perks, and Mage Perks are all Archetype Perks.
A Basic Perk has no restrictions on when it can be taken. An Advanced Perk is a stronger perk that is unavailable to you until you have taken 5 Basic Perks from the same group of perks. For example, you cannot take an Advanced Fighter Perk until you have taken 5 Basic Fighter Perks.
For a list of all the Perks, see the Perk List.
For more on how Perks work, see chapter 08 Tracker Boxes.

item.title: Persistent Condition
item.description: Persistent Conditions are Status Conditions that remain in effect, and retain their stacks, until a specified ending condition is met.

item.title: Persuasion
item.description: If ever the proxy Social Stat of Persuasion is asked for, it will be up to a Player to decide whether they are lying and should roll Deception, or telling the truth and should roll Sincerity Stat.

item.title: Player
item.description:
A person with a primary, Player Character that they are playing the role of. While the GM is technically playing the game with you, any time you see the term player in the rules or references, you should generally assume that refers to the players other than the GM.
This distinction will rarely matter in the Kleptonomicon, but it is a common distinction in TTRPGs and may matter for some Homebrew mechanics.

item.title: Player Character
item.description: A Player Character (or PC) is a character primarily created and roleplayed by one of the Players (not the Game Master.) Each Player Character has a Character Sheet that defines their overall strengths and capabilities.

item.title: Point Bank
item.description: A Point Bank is used to track a collection of Points, be that your Health, Vitality, Shield, or some other set of points from your Class or SRD/Appendix/Glossary/Constitution. Point Banks may also specify a maximum value that the Points will be reset to whenever a new Episode begins.

item.title: Prepare
item.description: When you Prepare an Ability, you get to add it to your Character Sheet for using later on. If the Prepared Ability describes an Expiration condition, then when that condition is met, the Ability will once again be removed from your Character Sheet, making it no longer usable (at least, until you can Prepare it again.)

item.title: Prestige Upgrade
item.description: Prestige Upgrades are some of the most powerful Ability Upgrades in the game and grant character-defining capabilities. One Prestige Upgrade is gained when you reach Level 5, 10, and 15.

item.title: Primary Archetype
item.description: Your Primary Archetype is chosen when creating your Player Character and grants you an extra 4 Archetype Levels in the Archetype chosen.

item.title: Primordial Language
item.description:
#insanity_condition
Primordial Language is a Language Family.
The Primordial Languages are Languages that pre-date the second creation (or are descended from such languages.) Attempting to communicate in one of these languages without knowing that exact Language may put you at risk of incurring a Status Condition, like Charmed (or, in the case of Void, incurring the #insanity_condition Fleeting Condition.)
Example Primordial Languages: Celestial, Deep, Draconic, Infernal, Void
The full list of Primordial Languages can be found in the Language List.

item.title: Prone
item.description: A Prone creature is on its knees or lying on its belly.

item.title: Reaction
item.description: A 'Reaction' Ability Time on an Ability means that that Ability can be performed at any point in an Encounter, not just on your Turn, provided that the Reaction's Reaction Trigger has occurred and you currently have a Beat to spend. If the Reaction is a Free Reaction, you do not need to spend a Beat. Only one Reaction or Free Reaction can be used per Reaction Trigger per character.

item.title: Reaction Trigger
item.description: A Reaction Trigger describes a set of events after which a Reaction can be used. Only one Reaction can be used per Reaction Trigger per character. If the Reaction Trigger would happen during someone else's Ability, such as when "someone targets you with an Ability", the triggering Ability is interrupted and is not fully resolved until after the Reaction is resolved.

item.title: Recovery
item.description: TODO

item.title: Requirement
item.description:
#point_banks #point_banks #point_banks #constitution
Some Abilities will list Requirements. Requirements can be generic things like hands or standing, or Requirements can be a specific type of point that you must spend from one of the #point_banks on your Character Sheet (Note: Your Shield, Health, and Vitality are #point_banks. You may also have #point_banks unique to your Class or #constitution.)
An Ability with Requirements will instantly be considered a Fail if you are lacking a Requirement at any point between the start of the Ability and when the Ability's Score and effect are determined. If points are Required, those points are only deducted at the time of determining the Ability's Score (but they must be available from the Ability's start to its scoring.)

item.title: Resistance
item.description:
A Resistance is a Defense that automatically halves (rounded down) all incoming Damage of a certain Damage Type or halves (rounded down) all incoming Stacks of a certain Status Condition. If the incoming Damage Type or Status Condition type does not match the ones listed in the Resistance then the Resistance does not take effect. Some Resistances may list additional requirements that must be met as well before the Resistance takes effect.
A Resistance may also list other effects. These side effects become active immediately after the matched Damage or Status Condition has been mitigated and applied.

item.title: Round
item.description:
Each Encounter is broken up into Rounds. During each Round, each Player and NPC take one Turn in the Turn Order that was decided upon during the Encounter's Setup Phase.
Each Round takes about 6 seconds. That said, each Turn is also fairly closes to 6 seconds, as they take place in parallel, albeit temporally staggered from one another.

item.title: Rumor Skill
item.description:
Rumor is an Artifice-based Skill that lets you do things like:

Recall current events (within the last 5 years.) Recall modern prominent figures. Recall modern customs, conspiracies, secrets, and the inner workings of governments, factions, and new-age religions.
Blend in with the locals or conform to etiquette. When interacting with a class of society with which your character has little experience, you may need to roll with Disadvantage.
Search a town for trustworthy merchants, local establishments, or leads on info about a subject. Find a fence or secret group located in the area.

item.title: Score
item.description:
Your Score is the final result of a Test, after all modifications (like Modifiers, Advantages, and Disadvantages, etc.) have been applied. If the GM asks for your Score, then they want the final result, rather than what you got on the die itself. The GM may even as for a "History Score" or a "Focus Score", which means you will make a Test with your History or Focus Modifier, respectively, then apply any other relevant modifications and report back the final result.
Your Score will often be compared to Score Ranges to determine the effect of the roll.

item.title: Score Range
item.description:
A Score Range is used to determine which effects each Score will bring about. Score Ranges* can often be found in Ability descriptions.
Score Ranges are written using a shorthand that is an inclusive range of numbers surrounded by square brackets.
The following are the common core Score Ranges:

[..6] Low Score.
[7..9] Mixed Score.
[10..] High Score.
Some descriptions will simply describe what happens when you Pass or Fail. In these cases, it only matters if you get a Low Score or not. Any Score that is a Mixed Score or higher counts as a Pass.

item.title: Secondary Archetype
item.description: Your Secondary Archetype is chosen when creating your Player Character and grants you an extra 2 Archetype Levels in the Archetype chosen.

item.title: Secondary Objective
item.description: A Secondary Objective is a hidden, side goal that may exist in any given situation. When Player(s) achieve these hidden goals, they can gin an extra Experience Point.

item.title: Setup Phase
item.description: The Setup Phase occurs at the very start of an Encounter. It is during the Setup Phase that the Turn Order is created. After the Turn Order has been created, starting Status Conditions for being surprised are assigned, if applicable.

item.title: Shape
item.description: A Shape specifies an area that can be affected by an Ability. When using an Ability with a Shape, you must specify the target area when you start that Ability. Later, when the Ability takes effect, all valid targets of the Ability that are within or touching the Shape will be affected by the Ability. For some longer Ability Times, this means creatures have a moment to try to escape the effects of the Ability.

item.title: Shield
item.description:
Your Shield is your first of three pools of points from which Damage will be subtracted. If your Shield reaches 0 and there is still Damage to be applied, the damage will then overflow into your Health. If that reaches 0 and there is still Damage to be applied, you will lose 1 Vitality, regardless of the amount of Damage remaining.
No Abilities will ever add to the points currently in your Shield Point Bank, but rather will always reset your Shield to a specific number. If your current Shield is higher than a new value, you can opt to keep the old value.

item.title: Sincerity Stat
item.description:
Sincerity is a Social Stat representing how well you can do things like:

Connect honestly or forthrightly with someone.
Intimidate someone through authentic posturing and/or honest threats.
Through authenticity, charm someone into viewing you or someone else as a friend or foe using the truth.
Perform heartfelt music, poetry, etc.

item.title: Size
item.description:
Your Size affects how you will interact with several mechanics of the game. There are 6 core Sizes. Below is a table of each Size along with examples and a unit reference of how big of an area they can block, in-case you are not playing with Theater of the Mind:

A creature can always use Movement to pass through the space of a creature more than one size larger or smaller. If a creature using the Grapple Ability is the same size or larger than you, they may gain an extra effect.

item.title: Skill
item.description: A Skill represents an general area of knowledge or technique. When a situation arises where a particular Skill comes into play, you may be asked to perform a Test to see how well you did. For Exploration Skills, your Exploration Skill Modifier is used as the primary Modifier for the Test. In the case of Social Skills, one of your Social Stats will be used as the main Modifier for the Test and you will need to roll with a Disadvantage unless you have the Social Skill asked for.

item.title: Slow Action
item.description:
A "Slow Action" must be started on your Turn by spending a Beat. At that time you must also choose your target, be that creature(s) or a target area for a Shape (the type of target will be described by the Slow Action.) The Slow Action won't do anything until the start of your next Turn, at which time you will determine the Ability's Score, and it will take effect based on what Score you got.
Between the time of starting your Slow Action and the start of your next Turn (when it would take effect) your Slow Actions can be interrupted in the following ways:

If you become Restrained.
If the target of Slow Action is invalid when it comes time to determine its Score. This includes if you target a point for a Shape (like the Cone Shape or the Line Shape,) then move (or are moved) in a way that makes that point invalid.
If one of the Requirements of the Slow Action cannot be met when it comes time to determine its Score.
Slow Action also gain Disadvantages for missing Components when it comes time to roll its Ability Skill Test (the same way Abilities do.)
If a Slow Action can target an area or a creature, you may choose targets that are initially invalid (due to being out or range, sight, etc.) It is only when the Slow Action takes effect that a target's validity will count.

item.title: Social Ability
item.description: Social Abilities are a type of Ability designed for social situations. Social Abilities are gained automatically as you gain Levels. The full list can be found in the Social Ability List.

item.title: Social Skill
item.description: The Social Skills represent your sway in more intense social situations. If you lack a Social Skill that is called for by a Test, you will be required to roll with a Disadvantage. The six Social Skills are Acting, Charm, Diplomacy, Intimidation, Performance, and Language -- with Performance and Language being broken down further into individual types of Performance and Language that you are learned in.

item.title: Social Stat
item.description:
The Social Stats represent your generic capabilities in social situations and will often be used as the primary Modifier of Tests in those social situations.
The three social stats are: Deception, Insight, and Sincerity Stat.
If ever the proxy Social Stat of Persuasion is asked for, it will be up to a Player to decide whether they lying (and should roll Deception) or telling the truth (and should roll Sincerity Stat.)

item.title: Spell Ability
item.description: A Spell Ability is a special type of Ability gained from taking Levels in the Mage Archetype.

item.title: Stack
item.description: A Stack is a type of point used to track the strength of a Status Condition or Zone.

item.title: Stat
item.description:
A Stat is a Modifier on your Character Sheet that determines how well you will perform in various Tests. The four types of Stats are:

Social Stats: Used in social Tests. Sometimes paired with Social Skills, but does not directly affect them.
Exploration Stats: Rarely rolled directly. Forms the starting point for Archetype Stat, Save Stat, and Exploration Skill Modifiers.
Archetype Stats: Used for most Abilities.
Save Stats: Used to resist extra effects from Abilities.

item.title: Status Condition
item.description: A Status Condition is a temporary debuff that gets applied to a Player Character or an NPC, often as a result of an Ability.

item.title: Straining
item.description:
Abilities with the "Straining" Penalty (or "Straining Abilities") impose one stack of Strained if you Pass their Test.
All future Straining Ability Tests have one Disadvantage for each stack of Strained that you have.

item.title: Tabletop Roleplaying Game
item.description: Tabletop Role Playing Games (or TTRPGs) are interactive storytelling adventures where players assume the roles of characters within a fictional world.

item.title: Tertiary Archetype
item.description: Your Tertiary Archetype is the Archetype left over after choosing your Primary Archetype and your Secondary Archetype. Your Tertiary Archetype, unlike the other Archetypes, will gain no extra Archetype Levels when creating your Player Character.

item.title: Test
item.description:
For a Test you will be required to roll dice then apply some alterations to the result of the dice to determine a Score.
A majority of the time you will roll a d10 and add a Modifier from your Character Sheet. Occasionally, you will need to perform other modifications to the roll before determining your Score, like rolling with an Advantage or a Disadvantage.
Your final Score of a Test is then used to determine how well your character performed the given task. The term 'Score' will always be used to refer to the final result of the Test (after all Modifiers, Advantages, Disadvantages, and other modifications have been applied.)

item.title: Theater of the Mind
item.description: "Theater of the Mind" refers to a style of play in descriptions and imagination are used instead of a map showing where Player Characters and enemies are. There are many helpful alternative rules on offer for playing using the Theater of the Mind.

item.title: Tinkering Skill
item.description:
Tinkering is an Artifice-based Skill that lets you do things like:

Craft, alter, dissect, or dismantle things at a physical level.
Disarm or alter a trap or mechanism.
Craft small, crude constructions from raw materials or perform unskilled or crude surgeries. (More complex tinkering in these areas may require specific tools and supplies or multiple Tests in a row.)

item.title: Trait Ability
item.description: A Trait Ability is an Ability that represents a capability that comes not from training, but from your fundamental makeup. You can gain a new Trait Ability whenever you Level Up to an odd Level.

item.title: Turn
item.description:
The Encounter phase is broken up into Rounds, during which each Player and NPC take one Turn in the Turn Order that was decided upon during the Encounter's Setup Phase.
During your Turn, you have a limited amount of Movement. You can also spend Beats to perform Actions or spend Beats to make progress on an Ability that has a longer Ability Time than an Action.
Each Round takes about 6 seconds. That said, each Turn is also fairly closes to 6 seconds, as they take place in parallel, albeit temporally staggered from one another.

item.title: Turn Order
item.description: The Turn Order is decided during the Setup Phase of an Encounter and determines the order in which each Player and NPC gets to take their Turn during each Round of the Encounter. Once an Encounter has started, the Turn Order will generally stay the same until the Encounter's End Phase.

item.title: Upgrade
item.description:
An Upgrade provides options for improving an Ability in some way. Any number of unlocked Upgrades can be applied with each use of the Ability, unless the Upgrade says otherwise. When using an Ability, you are not required to apply an Upgrade that you have chosen unless otherwise stated.
Upgrades are often rewarded when you gain a Level or when you choose certain Perks.
Prestige Upgrades are among the most powerful upgrades. They often grant character-defining capabilities that are not possible to attain in any other way.

item.title: Variant
item.description:
A Variant changes the base effects of an Item, Creature, or Ability.
All Variants are optional. You can choose one Variant when you first gain an Item or Ability or first summon or spawn a Creature. The Variant should remain fixed on its target until the Item or Ability is chosen again or swapped out or until the Creature is dismissed in some way.

item.title: Vitality
item.description:
Your Vitality Point Bank serves as the final pool of points from which damage is subtracted.
Damage is first subtracted from your Shield Point Bank. If your Shield reaches or is at 0, then all remaining damage is subtracted from your Health. If your Health reaches or is at 0, then any remaining damage causes you to lose one Vitality Point. Losing a Vitality Point inflicts a Wound. If your Health and Vitality both reach zero, then you die.
You can attempt to Dodge an incoming attack, provided you have a Dodge Point.

item.title: Weakness
item.description:
A Weakness is a Defense that automatically doubles all incoming Damage of a certain Damage Type or doubles all incoming Stacks of a certain Status Condition. If the incoming Damage Type or Status Condition type does not match the ones listed in the Weakness then the Weakness does not take effect. Some Weaknesses may list additional requirements that must be met as well before the Weakness takes effect.
A Weakness may also list other effects. These side effects become active immediately after the matched Damage or Status Condition has been amplified and applied.

item.title: Wealth Category
item.description: TODO

item.title: Wound
item.description:
You gain a Wound any time you take Damage to your Vitality. First roll a Wound Test to see which Core Fleeting Condition you will gain a stack of as a Persistent Condition. The Test is made with no Modifier. (These are in the same order on your Character Sheet, though you can randomize them in any way, so long as Bloodied has half the chance of occurring as the rest):

[0!] Gain a stack of Bloodied.
[1] Gain a stack of Blunted.
[2] Gain a stack of Charmed.
[3] Gain a stack of Dazed.
[4] Gain a stack of Frightened.
[5] Gain a stack of Restrained.
[6] Gain a stack of Silenced.
[7] Gain a stack of Slowed.
[8] Gain a stack of Susceptible.
[9] Gain a stack of Vulnerable.
[10!] No Effect.
For each Vitality you heal, you may remove 1 Wound and it's relevant Status Condition.

item.title: Zone
item.description:
A Zone is an area of the world that can affect characters, objects, and the world around them.
Most Zones follow a basic pattern: creatures that start their turn in the Zone or enter that type of Zone for the first time on their turn must Pass a Save or be affected in some negative way.
A Zone created by an Ability may override the default descriptions of a Zone, so be sure to read the Ability before resolving a Zone.

item.title: Fine Items List
item.description: See the Inventory Search Ability for more options.

item.title: Wand of Teleportation
item.description:
Wield Item. Movement Effect.
Requires: 1 Fine Wealth
A twisted stick of a transplanted tree with a split tip.
Wield to gain the following Action
Teleport Luck Action. Shooting Distance. Movement Effect. Target a free space that you can see within range. Luck Stat Score:
[..6] Roll on the Failure Table below.
[7..9] You end up where you wanted to go.
[..10] You end up where you wanted to go and can take 1 other creature with you. Failure Table (1d10):
[1] You teleport to the location you targeted, but... nothing comes with you. You are naked and Unarmed.
[2..5] Spin a pencil, bottle, or some other object. The direction it points in relation to you is the new direction that you will actually teleport in. The distance you chose is retained, if possible, or shortened until there is a free space you can teleport into.
[6..9] Nothing happens.
[10] You teleport twice as far as you intended to go (or as far a point as is visible and free within Sniping Distance.)
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] F: You have Disadvantage while using this item.
[7..9] C: The item works as normal.
[10..] A: You have Advantage while using the item.
[10!] S: You have two Advantages while using the item.

item.title: Alcohol
item.description:
Cost
Tags
*Can also be gained using other Wealth Skills, depending on the type of Alcohol. An Absinthe may be a Grey Good while a fine wine might be a Fine Good.
Gain the following Ability:
Drink Alcohol Time Target
Requirements
Test
Effect Grit Save Score:
[..6] You get more drunk. Gain 2 Stacks of the Status Conditions described below.
[7..9] You get a bit more drunk. Gain 1 Stack of one of the Status Conditions described below.
[10..] You handle the alcohol perfectly You can choose to gain Stacks of any of the following conditions as a Persistent Condition for 10 minutes:
Blunted, Dazed, Susceptible, or Vulnerable While you have max Stacks on all of the above Status Conditions, you gain a Stack of Bloodied as a Persistent Condition. If your Bloodied Condition ever causes you to lose a Vitality, you throw up and lose half of all Stacks gained from drinking Alcohol (which in-turn clears the Bloodied Condition.)
Item Grades:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..] C: The target regains an additional Recovery (2 total) and can possibly use both.
[10..] A: The target regains two additional Recoveries (4 total) and can possibly use them all.
[10!] S: The target instead regains all Recoveries and can possibly use them all.

item.title: Crowbar
item.description:
#noisy #loud
Tool Item (2 Solid/Blunt damage).
Requires: 1 General Wealth
While wielding, the "Forced Entry" Disadvantage of the Melee Attack does not apply (you can attempt to force entry as a #noisy action instead of a #loud action) and your Melee Attack deals 2 Solid/Blunt damage.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..] C: You gain the item.

item.title: Disguise
item.description:
Apparel Item (Body). Buff effect.
Requires: 1 General Wealth
While wearing a Disguise, you gain the following benefits:

You gain Advantage in Acting Skill Tests when pretending to be a member of the faction or group that matches the disguise.
You gain Advantage in Sneaking Skill Tests made within vision range of an enemy that is friendly with the faction that matches your disguise.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..] C: You gain a disguise of a faction of your choice that's in the area.
[10..] A: Your disguise is that of a higher-ranking faction member.
[10!] S: The disguise is accurate enough to also grant Advantage to Acting Skill Tests when pretending to be a specific person.

item.title: First Aid Kit
item.description:
Cost
Tags
A small pack of emergency medical supplies.
Gain the following Ability:
Use First Aid Kit Time Target
Requirements
Test
Effect Tinkering Score:
[..6] Restore 1 Recovery to target creature.
[7..] Restore 1 Recovery to target creature and the creature can immediately use a Reaction to use the Recoveries gained to restore 1d10 Health or 1 Vitality.
Item Grades:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..] C: The target regains an additional Recovery (2 total) and can possibly use both.
[10..] A: The target regains two additional Recoveries (4 total) and can possibly use them all.
[10!] S: The target instead regains all Recoveries and can possibly use them all.

item.title: General Items List
item.description:
See the Inventory Search Ability for more options.

Alcohol
Crowbar
Disguise
First Aid Kit
Melee Weapon
Ranged Weapon
Repair Kit
Restraining Kit

item.title: Melee Weapon
item.description:
Wield Item.
Requires: 1 General Wealth
Wield to modify your Melee Attack by increasing its Damage by 1 on a Passing Score and changing it's Damage Type based on your chosen Flavor. Each Melee Attack can only be affected by 1 Wield Item at a time.
In the same way, you can also modify your Ranged Attack. If you do, you become disarmed of the weapon until you can go and pick it up again.
Flavors (Choose 1):

Blunt. Solid/Blunt Damage.
Sharp. Solid/Sharp Damage.
Custom. With GM approval, you may be able to choose another Damage Type.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..] C: You gain the item.
[10..] A: You can add 1 Upgrade.
[10!] S: You can add a second Upgrade.
Upgrades:

Chain. Targets cannot use their Take Cover against your Melee Attack.
Magical. Common Weakness of ethereal beings.
Piercing. If you ever only deal damage to a target's Shield, you may also deal 1 damage directly to their Health, provided that their Health is not already at 0.
Pry. The Melee Attack Forced Entry Penalties does not apply (A Forced Entry is Noisy instead of Loud.)
Reach. Can make a Melee Attack from Spitting Distance.
Silver. Common Weakness of shapeshifters.
Sweeping. With a Passing Score, you can also deal 1 Damage of your Flavor's type to another creature within Melee Attack range of you.

item.title: Ranged Weapon
item.description:
Wield Item.
Requires: 1 General Wealth
Wield to modify your Ranged Attack, increasing its Damage by 1 on a Passing Score and changing other details based on Flavor. A Ranged Attack can only benefit from one Wield Item at a time.
Flavors (Choose 1):

Shoot Blunt. Solid/Blunt Damage at Shooting Distance.
Shoot Sharp. Solid/Sharp Damage at Shooting Distance.
Thrown Blunt. Fluid/Blunt Damage at Throwing Distance. Can ignore the "Close Combat" penalty. You do not need to retrieve the thrown item to use it again.
Thrown Sharp. Fluid/Sharp Damage at Throwing Distance. Can ignore the "Close Combat" penalty. You do not need to retrieve the thrown item to use it again.
Custom. With GM approval, you may be able to choose another Damage Type.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..] C: You gain the item.
[10..] A: You can add 1 Upgrade.
[10!] S: You can add a second Upgrade.
Upgrades:

Long Range. Increase the range from Throwing Distance to Shooting Distance or from Shooting Distance to Sniping Distance.
Magical. Common Weakness of ethereal beings.
Piercing. If you ever only deal damage to a target's Shield, you may also deal 1 damage directly to their Health, provided that their Health is not already at 0.
Silver. Common Weakness of shapeshifters.

item.title: Repair Kit
item.description:
Use Item. Healing effect.
Requires: 1 General Wealth
Use up this item to perform the following Ability:
Use Repair Kit Tinkering Action. Close Range. Healing effect. For a Construct or Undead Creature:
[..] Restore 1 Recovery to target creature.
[7..] The target can immediately use a Reaction to use the Recoveries gained to restore 1d10 Health or 1 Vitality. For other inanimate objects:
[..6] No effect.
[7..9] The object is stable and whole, but fragile.
[10..] The object is stable, whole, and as tough as it can be.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..] C: The target Construct or Undead regains an additional Recovery (2 total) and can possibly use both.
[10..] A: The target Construct or Undead regains two additional Recovery (4 total) and can possibly use them all.
[10!] S: The target Construct or Undead instead regains all Recoveries and can possibly use them all. Repairing objects counts as an automatic High Score.

item.title: Restraining Kit
item.description:
Wield Item. Debuff effect.
Requires: 1 General Wealth
Wield the Restraining Kit to gain the following Action:
Restrain Tinkering Action. Close Range. Debuff effect. The target must be willing or have the Held or Unconscious condition. Score Effect:
[..6] The target creature is not restrained.
[7..] The target creature gains two stacks of Restrained and Slowed as Persistent Conditions. The target can use an Action to attempt an Edge Save to break free again.
[10..] The target has a Disadvantage on all Edge Saves.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..] C: If Pass. The target has a Disadvantage on Edge Saves to escape their restraints (in addition to the normal Disadvantage gained.)
[10..] A: The target is also Silenced.
[10!] S: The target can only attempt their Edge Save once every 5 minutes.

item.title: Grey Items List
item.description: See the Inventory Search Ability for more options.

item.title: Lockpick
item.description:
Tool Item (2-handed). New Ability Effect.
Requires: 1 Grey Wealth
Wield Lockpicks to gain the following Action:
Lockpick Time Target
Test
Effect
[0!] Your lockpick breaks.
[..6] The lock is stuck or above your skill level.
[7..9] The lock remains locked, but you can try again.
[10..] The lock opens.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..9] C: The lockpick automatically fails against magical locks.
[10..] A: The lockpick can be used to pick magical locks.
[10!] S: You have an Advantage when picking locks.
Item Upgrade:

Careful.
Whenever you Fail a Lockpick Test, you can retry the Test once. If the retry is not a High Score, then the lock is stuck or above your skill level.

item.title: Poison
item.description:
Use Item. Debuff effect.
Requires: 1 Grey Wealth
Flavor: Choose one of the Core Fleeting Conditions.
Use up this item to perform one of the following Abilities:
Poison Weapon Time Target
Effect Apply Poison to the target weapon, affecting the next Basic Attack with that same weapon. A weapon can only have one Poison on it at a time and can be removed from a weapon by spending a Beat. The target of the Basic Attack must Pass a Grit Save or be affected by the Poison.
The poison can also be applied in other ways, like sneaking it into food or drink. Ask your GM before improvising.
Item Search Tiers determine the Poison's full effect:

[0!] F: You slipped up. You gain no item and you immediately gain a random stack of a Core Fleeting Condition until you next use a Recovery.
[..6] You gain no item.
[7..9] C: The target gain one stack of the chosen Fleeting Condition.
[10..] A: The target gains two stacks of the chosen Fleeting Condition.
[10!] S: The target gains a stack of the Fleeting Condition as a Persistent Condition for 1 day. Flip a coin. If you guess it, you have an antidote for the poison as well that can be taken or applied as an Action.
Item Upgrades:

Delayed Release.
When applying a Poison, you can specify a delay. The Poison will only take effect after it has affected the target and the delay has passed.
Complex.
You gain the following Flavor options when gaining new Poisons:
Paralyzed, Sleeping
Weaponized.
Gain the following Flavor options when gaining a new Poison:
Blinded, Deafened
* You can now Wield your Poisons to gain the following Ability: Splash Time Target
Test Save
Effect The target must Pass a Grit Save or suffer the effects of your Poison.

item.title: Book
item.description:
Passive Item. Buff effect.
Requires: 1 Obscure Wealth

A tome containing information about a specific topic.
This book's subject is that of a specific creature type, family, religion, faction, or other similar topic.
Once per Episode, you can study the book for 1 hour to gain one of the following benefits:

If the book's subject is a creature type, you gain an Advantage to your next Ability targeting that creature type.
Gain an Advantage on Knowledge Skill Tests relating to the book's subject for the rest of the Episode.
Ask the GM to reveal the strongest unknown Ability of a creature or person related to the book's subject.
Ask the GM to reveal a secret about the book's subject that may help with resolving your current situation. The GM may first ask for what type of information you may be seeking in the book.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..] C: You gain the item.
[10..] A: You may choose two options after studying the book.
[10!] S: This powerful tome takes only 5 minutes to study.

item.title: Cosmic Seed
item.description:
Use Item. Close range. Buff effect.
Requires: 1 Obscure Wealth
Plant Cosmic Seed Time Target
Requires
Effect Imagine a pocket universe (that fits the restrictions of the Cosmic Seed) then throw the Cosmic Seed into the target Rift's portal. The Rift becomes disconnected from its current secondary target and anything that was partway through the Rift is pushed randomly to one location or the other. The Rift then becomes connected to a brand new universe that reflects what you imagined. Whomever controlled the Rift when the Cosmic Seed was thrown into it can hereafter always create a new Rift connected to that same universe (even if they do not have the "Far" Upgrade for Rift.) If a Rift is already connected to a universe that you imagined and created with a previous Cosmic Seed, you can, instead, add on to your existing universe, expanding it by the limits of the new Cosmic Seed used. When you do so, you can rearrange or recreate the universe as you see fit. Any creature or object that would be harmed or trapped by the rearranging of the universe is instead harmlessly ejected from the universe to a free space within Swinging Distance of the Rift.
The universe you create with the Cosmic Seed is limited in size based on its Item Grade, but can otherwise contain as many rooms, features, or items as you would like. The newly created universe can also contain Zones from the Zone List in any quantity or size you desire. The universe can appear to be endless, but reaching the edges will cause the creature to wrap to the other side of the universe or they will feel like they are moving, despite not actually moving. Any items within the universe are bound to it. Attempting to remove them will cause them to crumble and vanish.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..9] C: The universe created can be up to around 25 sq m (250 sq ft or the size of a medium-sized RV.)
[10..] A: The universe created can be up to around 100 sq m (1000 sq ft or the size of a small 2-bedroom house.)
[10!] S: You can also create a denizen of the universe. It can be any creature from the Creature List. The denizen is bound to that universe and will die if it leaves it. You control and play the creature (unless you would rather the GM play it for you.)

item.title: Hag Stone
Mana Potion
item.description:
Use Item. Close range. Buff effect.
Requires: 1 Obscure Wealth
Consume as an Action to remove one stack of Strained.
Item Search Tiers:

[..9] You gain no item.
[10..] A: You gain the item.
[10!] S: You can remove all stacks of Strained.

item.title: Obscure Items List
item.description: See the Inventory Search Ability for more options.

item.title: Resurrection Stone
item.description:
Use Item. Close range. Buff effect.
Requires: 1 Obscure Wealth
Gain the following Ability that consumes this Item:
Use Resurrection Stone
Time Target
Requires
Test
Effect Mage Skill Score:
[..6] No Effect. The 1 Vitality cost is not refunded.
[7..9] Gain a stack of Exhausted. The target returns to life with its Vitality restored, but no Health.
[10..] Gain a stack of Exhausted. The target returns to life with its Vitality restored along with half its Health, rounded down.

item.title: Spell Scroll
item.description:
Use Item.
Requires: 1 Obscure Wealth
Cast a Spell Ability contained on this scroll. The Spell Ability's usual requirements, like Ability Time and Components, must still be met. The Spell Ability is cast with your Caster Skill or the Caster Skill of the person who created the Spell Scroll. This Spell Scroll is consumed if you get a Passing Score when casting the Spell Ability.
Item Search Tiers:

[0!] You slipped up. The GM can cast a random Spell Ability on you. If you are Level 5 or higher, the GM can add an Upgrade. If you are Level 10 or higher, the GM can add a second Upgrade.
[..5] F:
Choose a Spell Ability you know. It can, optionally, include your Upgrades.
[7..] C:
Choose any Spell Ability. It can have up to 2 of any of its Upgrades.
Choose a Spell Ability you know. You can give it an extra Upgrade.
[10..] A:
Choose any Spell Ability. It can have up to 5 of any of its Upgrades.
Choose a Spell Ability you know. You can give it an extra 2 Upgrades.
[10!] S:
With the GM's approval, improvise a Spell Ability that does not otherwise exist in the game. (This Spell Ability does not need to be chosen at the time of creation, but can be filled in later.)

item.title: Spellblinding Incense
item.description:
Use Item. Stealth Effect.
Requires: 1 Obscure Wealth
A stick of purple incenses that smells of sage and pine.
Burn the incense as an Action. The smoke will clear any ethereal afterimages of magic within 1u that was cast in the last 10 minutes or that will be cast in the next 10 minutes. You can use Movement to clear additional areas for up to 2 Turns (or 12 seconds.)
Clearing ethereal afterimages makes it so the See ability and the Sensing Skill will be incapable of detecting that magic. That said, active magic and auras can still be seen and sensed.
Item Search Tiers:

[..6] You gain no item.
[7..9] C: The incense has no effect on active magic and auras.
[10..] A: The incense can muddle active magic and auras, giving observers a Disadvantage when identifying.
[10!] S: You gain 2 Grade-A incense.

item.title: Special Item List
item.description:
Special Items are categorized into 3 item grades. Special Items cannot be Actualized by players, but are instead given out by the GM. The Special Item Grades continue on above the normal Item Grades:

S - Special Items
SS - Strange Special items
SSS - Singular Strange Special Items

One-of-a-kind items with rarity unmatched by any others.

Cosmic Egg Use Item. Action. 1 Mile Range. Healing Effect. A silver egg with a metal serpent etched into its surface, much like the one that gave birth to Phanes themself (one of the four horsemen of creation.) The cosmic egg is one of the first ingredients needed to create a Philosopher's Stone. The egg contains within it a powerful healing light. As an Action, you smash the egg, releasing a flood of healing light flows from you into injured creatures around you. You can restore the health and vitality of any number of creatures within range. Creatures healed by this item are also cured of all diseases and any effect making them blinded or deafened. This item has no effect on undead or constructs. The Cosmic Egg can also be cultivated with the goal of hatching it. The egg normally takes a millennium to hatch, though time magic can help speed it up. Once hatched, the egg creates a new plane of existence. The person who bore the egg for the longest amount of time before the egg hatched becomes a god of the new plane that is able to shape and rule it how they please.

Eye of Chronos Equipment. Jealous of [AA..AAA]. Buff Effect. A translucent black eye glittering with a cosmic view of the Zodiac Wheel. The god Chronos (one of the four horsemen of creation) is a cruel and relentless god. If he knew you were using his eye, there's no telling what he would do. When your eye is replaced by this one, the wearer can gain the ability to peek a moment into the future. Requires Friendship. Jealous of [AA..AAA].
[-2..-1] Enemy. The eye lies to you. All rolls you make must be made with Disadvantage. If the die lands on a value greater than 10, your friendship with this item goes up by 1.
[0..1] Neutral. The eye simply watches you. If the die for a roll you make is greater than 10, you can add 1 to the friendship with this item.
[2] Friend. The eye shows you the future. You cannot be surprised and have Advantage on all rolls you make. In addition, any creatures targeting you must roll with Disadvantage. Whenever you roll a Critical Failure, your friendship with the eye resets to -1.

Philosophers Stone Equipment. Close range. Healing and transmutation effects. Once per day, you can chip a small piece off the philosophers stone. The missing portion of the stone will regrow the next day. If you attempt to chip off a second piece, the stone shatters into 5 pieces. The smaller pieces of the stone will not grow or regenerate. A chip of the stone can be used in two ways:
As an Action, you can prepare a powerful healing potion. You dissolve the chip in a cup of wine, creating a potion lasts for 1 day. As an Action, you can drink the potion or apply the potion to another creature in Close range. The target of the potion regains all of its Health and Vitality. All Fleeting Conditions end on the target as well as Persistent Conditions that involve being charmed, frightened, paralyzed, or stunned. If the creature is Prone, it can use a Free Reaction to stand up. The potion has no effect on undead or constructs.
As an Action, you can dissolve the stone into a portion of metal to create gold. In this way, you can convert 1 of any Wealth into 1 Fine Wealth.

Potion of Invulnerability Use item. 10 Minutes duration. Warding effect. A small potion bottle filled with a thick, metallic liquid. After consuming the potion, you gain a 100 defense against all damage for 10 minutes.

Scissors of Atropos Equipment. Action. 12" range. Damage effects. A pair of ragged golden scissors that belong to Atropos herself. While they do not look sharp on the Material Plane, their embodiment on the Astral Plane is sharp enough to cut the very threads of life themselves. As an Action, you can attempt to cut the life thread of a creature within range. Roll your Caster Skill against the target's current Health or Vitality, whichever is larger. If you succeed in rolling equal to or higher than that target number, the target dies instantly. If you fail, the fates deal 1 Damage directly to your Vitality.

God "Aether"
Astral Projection
Necromancy. 1 Hour cast. Special duration. 10 ft Range. Teleportation. V, S.
You and up to eight willing creatures within range project your astral bodies into the Astral Plane (the Spell Ability fails and the casting is wasted if you are already on that plane). The material body you leave behind is unconscious and in a state of suspended animation; it doesn't need food or air and doesn't age.
Your astral body resembles your mortal form in almost every way, replicating your game statistics and possessions. The principal difference is the addition of a silvery cord that extends from between your shoulder blades and trails behind you, fading to invisibility after 1 foot. This cord is your tether to your material body. As long as the tether remains intact, you can find your way home. If the cord is cut--something that can happen only when an effect specifically states that it does--your soul and body are separated, killing you instantly.
Your astral form can freely travel through the Astral Plane and can pass through portals there leading to any other plane. If you enter a new plane or return to the plane you were on when casting this Spell Ability, your body and possessions are transported along the silver cord, allowing you to re-enter your body as you enter the new plane. Your astral form is a separate incarnation. Any damage or other effects that apply to it have no effect on your physical body, nor do they persist when you return to it.
The Spell Ability ends for you and your companions when you use your action to dismiss it. When the Spell Ability ends, the affected creature returns to its physical body, and it awakens.
The Spell Ability might also end early for you or one of your companions. A successful dispel magic Spell Ability used against an astral or physical body ends the Spell Ability for that creature. If a creature's original body or its astral form drops to 0 hit points, the Spell Ability ends for that creature. If the Spell Ability ends and the silver cord is intact, the cord pulls the creature's astral form back to its body, ending its state of suspended animation.
If you are returned to your body prematurely, your companions remain in their astral forms and must find their own way back to their bodies, usually by dropping to 0 hit points.
God of "Chaos"
Blade of Disaster
Conjuration. 1 Bonus Action. 1 Minute cast. 60 ft Range. (Melee Attack). Force effect. C, V, S.
You create a blade-shaped planar rift about 3 feet long in an unoccupied space you can see within range. The blade lasts for the duration. When you cast this Spell Ability, you can make up to two melee Spell Ability attacks with the blade, each one against a creature, loose object, or structure within 5 feet of the blade. On a hit, the target takes 4d12 force damage. This attack scores a critical hit if the number on the d20 is 18 or higher. On a critical hit, the blade deals an extra 8d12 force damage (for a total of 12d12 force damage). As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the blade up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see and then make up to two melee Spell Ability attacks with it again. The blade can harmlessly pass through any barrier, including a wall of force.
Gate
Conjuration. 1 Action cast. 1 Minute dur. 60 ft range. Control effect (...). C, V, S.
You conjure a portal linking an unoccupied space you can see within range to a precise location on a different plane of existence. The portal is a circular opening, which you can make 5 to 20 feet in diameter. You can orient the portal in any direction you choose. The portal lasts for the duration.
